text: I can't turn a private channel into a public one, but we can delete the private channel and then I can recreate it. You'll need to invite me to the private channel.

text:
This was going to be a reply to Yair, but I decided to break it out so that more people would see it and have the chance to weigh in.

Here are my reasons for being against the creation of subject-specific channels. Please show me the error of my ways, or voice support, or suggest alternative ways we could support more subject-centric discussion that limits the bad kind of fervor.

• Most people here in this community are (or would benefit from being) interested in _everything._
• Fewer channels are easier to follow, which is important if you are interested in everything.
• Every existing person will need to be told about each new channel. Lots of people check the slack infrequently and miss those messages, even after multiple repeats.
• Each new person will need to be told about all existing channels. We haven't yet found a good way to do this, other than including channels in the default set. Having a lot of default channels can be overwhelming. People already need to learn that things like <#CCL5VVBAN|share-your-work>, <#CFQUMT7M3|>, and <#C0120A3L30R|two-minute-week> have special rules, so I want to avoid making the newcomer experience even more intense.
• New people might not know that the point of subject-specific channels is that they're "safe spaces" for true believers :), so this will need to be communicated too.
• Whenever we do want to have a discussion about the merits of (say) FP vs logic programming, that stuff will still end up in <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together>, because the subject channels are safe spaces. So we've kept all our flame wars front-and-center and moved the more thoughtful discussions off to the sidelines.
• When posting something interesting that intersects multiple interests, you need to make a decision about which channel to post it in. Some people post to general. Some people post to a subject channel. Some do both. None of these are _great_.

text:
One of the things I'd like to work on is a way we can quickly signal to one another when a conversation appears to be heading in an unproductive direction. Kartik's :thread-please: (`:thread-please:`) emoji is great, as a signal that I take to mean both "This top-level reply should have gone into a thread" and even "This in-thread reply probably should have been, or should now become, the start of a new thread." How do you all feel about creating our own emoji-style reactions as this sort of signal? I wouldn't want a bunch of these, but it might be nice to have one or two more like this. Perhaps something to say, "This comment feels a bit rage-y — anyone who is going to reply, please don't take the bait"?

(I view this as an incentive design problem, and thus find it very stimulating)

text:
<@UC2A2ARPT> your comment leads me to wonder if we can improve on `:thread-please:`, because I intended it differently than you interpreted it. What I've been doing is tagging _comments_ that were on the top-level but I thought should have created a new thread. Maybe it needs a tweak for clarity.

FWIW, I saw others use it the way I expected yesterday when I replied at the top level :tada: :sweat_smile:

Your idea of suggesting a response go to a new thread is also great, as is just `:ragey:` for "take it to random". Suddenly I like reacji a whole lot more.

text: They come out narrow in the web interface. You don't get notified of great conversations just because you missed the start of one. Even then it's hard to find the follow thread button so I mostly don't bother. The mobile app handles it badly but I can't recall the details of that as I don't use it there often enough. I'll get back to you on that one..

text:
Without threading, single topics dominate a page, pushing off or obscuring other issues people raise

text:
<@UE6EFEPTQ> your points are valid. _However_, we seem to be stuck with these problems for now. And in the world we do have, the custom seems to be overwhelmingly in favor of threading. So, would you be amenable to joining rather than fighting them/us?

(If others feel similarly to Duncan, please :thumbsdown: this comment. I'm curious to hear from a potentially large silent minority. I actually mildly prefer zero-threading as well, out of similar FOMO motivations to Duncan's.)
